results.headline: Dreams of Flight, National Pride and Love à la Bollywood
results.summary_short: “Hawaizaada” wraps itself in a love story, but its main focus is on a pair of aviation pioneers in India who are said to have designed an airplane in 1895, before the Wright brothers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hawaizaada

results.headline: Exploring the Limits in a Man’s World
results.summary_short: In “Girlhood,” Céline Sciamma revels in the risky, reckless exuberance of adolescence and in the sheer joy of filming it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girlhood

results.headline: A Medieval Time on a Planet Far Away
results.summary_short: “Hard to Be a God,” the last movie by the Russian filmmaker Aleksei German, is set on another planet still in the throes of the Middle Ages.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hard to Be a God

results.headline: Marked for Death After Helping a Friend
results.summary_short: “Wild Card,” a remake of William Goldman’s “Heat,” stars Jason Stratham as a security consultant caught up in violent confrontations in Las Vegas.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Card

results.headline: Hostages of Racism
results.summary_short: In “Supremacy,” directed by Deon Taylor, a white supremacist just released from prison invades a black family’s farmhouse.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Supremacy

results.display_title: Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of
results.headline: Back When They Were Fab
results.summary_short: In “Backstreet Boys: Show ’Em What You’re Made Of,” members of that boy band reminisce, relax and occasionally rehearse.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of

results.headline: With Ability to Script Success, What Could Go Wrong?
results.summary_short: “Project Almanac,” portrayed as if the film’s footage were shot by the characters, traces a group of friends as they try to manipulate their lives through time travel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Project Almanac

results.headline: Take My Iraqi Niece, Please
results.summary_short: In Sean Mullin’s “Amira & Sam,” an Army veteran and aspiring comedian becomes the protector of his old Iraqi translator’s beautiful relative.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amira & Sam

results.headline: Race Relations on the Family Tree
results.summary_short: In “Black or White,” Kevin Costner and Octavia Spencer battle each other for custody of their biracial granddaughter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black or White

results.headline: Embedded With the E. T. Fighters
results.summary_short: The low-budget “Alien Outpost” is shaped like a boots-on-the-ground documentary but is more akin to a futuristic war movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alien Outpost

results.headline: Jewish American Pilots Fighting for Israel
results.summary_short: The documentary “Above and Beyond” recounts the story of Jewish American pilots who secretly fought for Israel during its War of Independence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Above and Beyond

results.headline: A Fury Arrives. Hypocrisy, Too.
results.summary_short: An unflinching exploration of jihadists is the focus of Abderrahmane Sissako’s film “Timbuktu.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Timbuktu

results.headline: Young, French and Desperate for a Ride Out of Town
results.summary_short: “My Name Is Hmmm ...” tells the story of an 11-year-old girl running away from a sexually abusive father.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Je m'appelle Hmmm...

results.headline: Parent and Child as Two Volcanoes Under One Roof
results.summary_short: In Xavier Dolan’s “Mommy,” a mother and her troubled son confront each other when he returns home after a stint in group living.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mommy

results.headline: Not Quite Sure About Happily Ever After
results.summary_short: In “We’ll Never Have Paris,” a florist on the cusp of proposing to his longtime girlfriend begins to wonder what it would be like to see other women.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We'll Never Have Paris

results.headline: A Sensual Utopia Driven by Ritual and Release
results.summary_short: “The Duke of Burgundy,” by Peter Strickland, is an exquisite hothouse flower of high-toned eroticism, evoking the director’s unabashed love of old exploitation movies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Duke of Burgundy

results.headline: When Hunky Neighbor Becomes Homicidal Stalker
results.summary_short: Jennifer Lopez plays a teacher who comes to regret a one-night stand in “The Boy Next Door.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boy Next Door

results.headline: To Fight, Flee or Simply Join Them?
results.summary_short: “Son of a Gun” teams a hardened criminal portrayed by Ewan McGregor with his 19-year-old protégé in a brutish Australian action-adventure fantasy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Son of a Gun

results.headline: Pleasure, Dealt Painfully
results.summary_short: In ‘R100,” by Hitoshi Matsumoto, a salaryman hires a sadism service to deliver dominatrixes wielding punishment on a regular basis.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of R100

results.headline: Comes an Aristocrat, Mustache Flaring
results.summary_short: In “Mortdecai,” Johnny Depp plays a rakish aristocrat who hopes to pay off an enormous tax debt by tracking down and selling a missing Goya painting.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mortdecai
